summary: The study was published at Oregon State University, Corvallis, OR 97331, USA . The study looked at mice housed at room temperature at 22°C . The authors say mice are typically housed at temperatures below their thermoneutral zone .
Mice are a commonly used model organism for studying how factors, such as physical activity, influence aging-related bone loss . Mice typically maintained at housing temperatures of 20–26 °C .

There is evidence and concern that maintaining mice under sustained cold stress may influence experimental results as well as hinder the translatability of preclinical research findings to human physiology . The thermoneutral zone for C57BL/6 J mice varies from ~29 to 34 °C .

The objectives of this study were to determine whether a small (4°C) difference in temperature (22 °C versus 26 °A) influences bone microarchitecture in growing female mice . To date, no detailed temperature response study on bone has been performed in mice .

Mice were decapitated by decapitation and housed in identical cages in separate rooms in the same vivarium . Mice in the baseline group were individually housed and sacrificed 1 week later . The other three groups of mice were maintained at their respective temperatures and housing conditions until 18 weeks of age .

Female C57BL/6 J mice sacrificed at baseline (6 weeks old) or housed under the following conditions (n=10/group): 22 °C and single housed, 26°C, or 22°C . Female mice were sacrificed at 6 weeks old or housed at room temperature (22°C)

Area, area, BMC, and BMD increased in all treatment groups compared to baseline . However, there were no differences among treatment groups . Effects of housing temperature and group housing on midshaft femur diaphysis microarchitecture were studied .

Single housing mice at 26 °C attenuated, but did not prevent, cold stress-induced bone loss . Cancellous bone volume fraction was 54% higher in mice housed at 26°C compared to mice housed  at 22 Cupelous . Trabecular separation was higher in all treatment groups compared to baseline .
Figure 6: Bone volume fraction, connectivity density, trabecular number, and number of vertebra length decreased in mice .

Laboratory mice are typically housed at 22 °C, which is within the thermoneutral comfort zone for humans but well below thermoneneutral for mice . mice maintain their core body temperature through adaptive thermogenesis when the ambient temperature is below thernneutral .

The study found that an increase in housing temperature of individually housed mice from 22 °C to 26 C influenced bone mass and microarchitecture in female mice . It significantly attenuated, but did not prevent, bone loss in distal femur metaphysis .

Mice are transported to the ISS and housed in rodent habitats with a reported temperature range of 26–28 °C . Mice aboard the ISS are unable to huddle as efficiently or assume postural positions to reduce heat loss as ground controls . Study found that mice aboard the . ISS are more dependent upon adaptive thermogenesis to maintain core body temperature .
Study: Energy reallocation to breeding performance through improved nest building in laboratory mice . Study: Mice reallocated energy to breeding .
Hindlimb unloading rodent model: technical aspects . Hindlimbs were published in J. Appl. Physiol. (1985) 2002;92 .
